headline: Oil and Gas Exploration Ban Repealed as Contentious Crown Minerals Bill Passes Final Hurdle
summary: Parliament was dominated by the final passage of the controversial Crown Minerals Amendment Bill, officially repealing the 2018 ban on new offshore oil and gas exploration. The Government also introduced major reforms to the public service, while facing intense questioning over the cost of living and low pay offers for nurses and teachers during a heated Question Time.

topicSummaries.topic: Crown Minerals Bill Passes Third Reading, Reversing Oil and Gas Exploration Ban
topicSummaries.content: The Government successfully passed the third and final reading of the Crown Minerals Amendment Bill, officially reversing the previous government's 2018 ban on new petroleum exploration permits outside of onshore Taranaki. Proponents, led by Minister for Energy Simon Watts, argued the move is critical for New Zealand's energy security, will attract investment, and will prevent reliance on higher-emission imported coal. The Opposition fiercely contested the bill, with Labour's Dr Megan Woods and the Green Party's Steve Abel arguing it undermines climate change commitments, risks trade agreements, and offers a false solution to energy affordability, labelling it an ideological move that benefits multinational corporations over New Zealanders.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr Megan Woods (Labour—Wigram)
keyExchanges.quote: This is a Government that has no plan to make sure that New Zealanders have access to affordable and secure energy... It shouts loud and clear that that is where their priorities lie. They will put oil and gas corporations ahead of New Zealand taxpayers every day of the week, and this bill lays that out in black and white.

keyExchanges.speaker: Simon Court (ACT)
keyExchanges.quote: Today marks the end of an era—a really bad one. It marks the end of a six-year reign of economic vandalism and energy illiteracy by the previous New Zealand Labour Government... This bill replaces ideology with evidence—imagine that—it ends six years of economic damage from Labour's damaging economic policies, and it tells the world that New Zealand is once again open for investment.

topicSummaries.topic: Major Public Service Overhaul Bill Introduced to 'Get Back to Basics'
topicSummaries.content: The Government introduced the Public Service Amendment Bill for its first reading, aiming to refocus the public service on efficiency, performance, and political neutrality. Minister for the Public Service Judith Collins stated the bill restores purpose and discipline by strengthening merit-based appointments, making chief executive reappointments contestable, and removing specific provisions for diversity, equity, and inclusion, arguing these are covered by other laws. Labour and the Greens strongly opposed the bill, raising concerns that it politicises the public service, weakens pay equity commitments, and rolls back progress on creating a workforce that reflects New Zealand society.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Judith Collins (Minister for the Public Service)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill is about restoring purpose, discipline, and professionalism to the Public Service... It refocuses the Public Service on delivering results, not processes; and it puts the needs of taxpayers—as the people who fund and rely on these services—front and centre.

keyExchanges.speaker: Camilla Belich (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This is another bill which is walking back New Zealand's commitment—and in the Public Service, it has been since 1960—towards leading pay equity and gender fairness within New Zealand. It is shocking and, I think, a terrible thing to include that within a bill that could have been an opportunity to really move the Public Service forward.

topicSummaries.topic: Ministers Grilled on Cost of Living and 'Effective Pay Cuts' for Nurses and Teachers
topicSummaries.content: During a fiery Question Time, Opposition MPs challenged the Government on its commitment to women's economic empowerment and cost of living relief. Labour's Carmel Sepuloni repeatedly questioned low pay offers for female-dominated professions like nursing and teaching, describing them as "effective pay cuts". Labour's Barbara Edmonds highlighted the struggles of families, quoting community advocates who say the cost of living crisis has worsened. The Government, represented by Ministers Judith Collins and Chris Bishop, defended its position by stating Ministers do not interfere in pay negotiations and that its focus on lowering inflation and providing tax cuts is the most effective form of relief.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Carmel Sepuloni (Labour—Kelston)
keyExchanges.quote: How can a 1 percent pay offer, an effective pay cut for secondary school teachers, align with her commitment to support women's economic empowerment?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Judith Collins (Attorney-General)
keyExchanges.quote: I've made it pretty clear, haven't I, that the Minister does not engage in negotiations at the bargaining table, and nor, might I say, does the Nurses Organisation, having walked away from the bargaining table.

topicSummaries.topic: Energy Prices and Dairy Lobby Influence Under Scrutiny
topicSummaries.content: The Government faced pointed questions from the Green Party regarding energy affordability and environmental policy. Green MP Scott Willis pressed the Minister for Energy on rising power bills and consumer complaints, questioning the value of fossil fuel subsidies over direct investment in renewables. Later, Green MP Steve Abel challenged the Minister of Agriculture on the perceived influence of the dairy lobby on freshwater policy, citing a recent nitrate contamination incident in Gore. Ministers defended their approach, stating they are focused on increasing renewable generation to improve competition and that freshwater policy reform is being developed through a wide and transparent public consultation process.

keyExchanges.speaker: Steve Abel (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Does he dispute the findings of the Newsroom investigation that showed the dairy lobby has enjoyed privileged and disproportionate access to Ministers and officials, that led to the removal of freshwater protections?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Todd McClay (Minister of Agriculture)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, yes, I do, absolutely, because it is not correct. I also think that private money going into news organisations to run stories in itself is something that should be considered... What I can confirm for that member is that the most consulted sectors through targeted consultation of the freshwater process were councils and iwi.

conclusion: The Government decisively advanced its core deregulatory and reform agenda, cementing a major reversal in energy policy while facing a wall of opposition accusing it of undermining environmental protections, pay equity, and public service integrity.
